image.altText: A sign saying "Adelaide Writers Week" in front of a park.

props.synopsis: Nearly a dozen former leaders of the Adelaide Festival are calling for Randa Abdel-Fattah to be reinvited to Writers' Week, adding to a mounting crisis over the Palestinian-Australian author's exclusion from the literary festival.

title.children: Former Adelaide Festival leaders label Palestinian author's exclusion 'grave mistake'

image.altText: An old man with a long white beard wearing a bucket hat stands in front of an outdoor tin and stone structure.

props.synopsis: Off the Strzelecki Track in outback South Australia lies the gallery of Alf Talc, so named for the artworks he carves out of soft, powdery talc.

title.children: Talc Alf's eccentric gallery a memorable stop in outback SA

image.altText: A shirtless man and his dog sit in front of a fountain.

props.synopsis: South Australia's Riverland will swelter through yet another day in the mid-to-high 40s on Friday and will have to wait until the weekend for a reprieve.

title.children: Murray River visitors hit with sweltering heatwave during peak season

image.altText: A man resting his chin on his hand

props.synopsis: Four of the most senior public servants working on South Australia's algal bloom have rejected allegations that departmental staff had been instructed not to investigate the cause of the ecological disaster until after March's state election.

title.children: 'Absolutely no direction' to stop algal bloom investigations, public service chiefs say

image.altText: A man carrying documents outside a court

props.synopsis: South Australian MP Nick McBride, who has been charged with aggravated assault, says home detention will make him "more focused" on his electorate ahead of the SA election in March.

title.children: MP accused of assault says home detention makes him 'more wedded' to electorate

image.altText: Carriages from a derailed freight train.

props.synopsis: The derailment of a freight train on a key section of railway in South Australia is affecting all transcontinental train services as heatwave conditions in the area impact the pace of recovery works.

title.children: A derailed freight train has shut a key railway line. Here's what we know

image.altText: A wind turbine silhouetted against a clear sky.

props.synopsis: The Kentbruck Green Energy Hub would include wind turbines up to 270m tall, and be built inside active pine plantations, but its location has worried conservationists.

title.children: Planned wind farm next to Ramsar-listed wetlands passes 'significant' hurdle

image.altText: A two-storey building with a new garden, park benches and shade

props.synopsis: South Australia's doctors' union has raised concerns that clinicians were distressed when asked to admit more patients at a new mental health unit at Noarlunga Hospital when staffing levels were "not clinically safe".

title.children: Staff at new Adelaide mental health unit 'visibly distressed and crying', union says

image.altText: a woman seen in her car wearing a beanie and a jacket

props.synopsis: The new footage, reposted by the White House on social media, was recorded by the agent involved, and reveals the confrontation that led to the shooting as well as him swearing at her immediately afterwards.

title.children: New video emerges of ICE agent shooting woman in Minneapolis

image.altText: Hundreds sit at a Swiss memorial service for the New years day ski bar fire.

props.synopsis: Forty people died and 116 people were injured in the fire at the Swiss ski bar on January 1.

title.children: Switzerland holds national day of mourning for fatal ski bar fire

image.altText: People stand in the street as cars burn in front of them

props.synopsis: Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has remained defiant amid nationwide protests, saying his regime would not back down in the "face of saboteurs."

title.children: Iran's leader accuses protesters of trying to 'please' Trump

image.altText: A couple stand at a doorway

props.synopsis: Thousands of North Queensland residents within a cyclone warning zone are without telecommunications services after suspected copper thieves cut cables.

title.children: Thousands affected as suspected copper thieves cut cables in cyclone warning zone

image.altText: Marta Kostyuk smiles

props.synopsis: Marta Kostyuk crushed world number six Jessica Pegula in less than an hour after Aryna Sabalenka powered past Karolína Muchová to reach a third consecutive Brisbane International final.

title.children: Ukrainian underdog sets up Sabalenka final with 55-minute annihilation

image.altText: Buildings on a hillside behind the silhouette of a person walking.

props.synopsis: The ABC hears from residents of Venezuela's capital, Caracas, about the struggles of daily life and their hopes and fears after American intervention.

title.children: 'Rich have become poor': Venezuelans describe their daily struggle

image.altText: A woman in a black strappy top with her hair pulled up into a bun is turned away from the camera.

props.synopsis: New research shows thousands of alcohol products remain on Australian shelves without mandated pregnancy warning labels.

title.children: Mums who drank during pregnancy call for universal alcohol warnings

image.altText: Donald Trump wearing a suit while speaking into a microphone.

props.synopsis: The US president has pivoted to portraying capturing former Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro as as a new-found economic opportunity for the US, seizing tankers carrying Venezuelan oil.

title.children: Trump says oil executives will have 'total safety' if they invest in Venezuela

image.altText: A large grey turtle with sand on its back moves through the sand near multicoloured plastics.

props.synopsis: A beach on a remote island, and home to nesting turtles, is annually overwhelmed by tonnes of plastic garbage. Christmas Island is doing what it can to help stem the never-ending tide of pollution.

title.children: Greta Beach should be pristine. Instead, it's choking on a tsunami of plastic waste

image.altText: A man and woman dance while performing on a stage surrounded by confetti.

props.synopsis: China has restricted access to South Korean pop culture since 2016, when Seoul received US anti-missile technology. Warmer bilateral ties are spurring optimism that will change.

title.children: The Korean Wave may splash back into China amid thawing ties

image.altText: A composite image showing the grok logo with overlayed with comments from X.

props.synopsis: For more than a week, X's AI bot Grok has been generating sexual images of women and children at the request of other users, even when they ask it not to.

title.children: Elon Musk limits X's AI image generator over non-consensual sexual imagery

image.altText: Samples of rare earth minerals in vials

props.synopsis: India was also invited to attend the meeting, but it is unclear if it has accepted the invitation.

title.children: Australia to discuss critical minerals with G7 in Washington next week

image.altText: An electronic billboard about 'The Very Hungry Wall'.

props.synopsis: A concrete wall built on the picturesque waterfront of a small Tasmanian town has prompted confusion and concern from residents.

title.children: A Tasmanian council built a wall. It hasn't gone down well

image.altText: An old man with a long white beard wearing a bucket hat stands in front of an outdoor tin and stone structure.

props.synopsis: Off the Strzelecki Track in outback South Australia lies the gallery of Alf Talc, so named for the artworks he carves out of soft, powdery talc.

title.children: Talc Alf's eccentric gallery a memorable stop in outback SA

image.altText: Beakers water contamination

props.synopsis: The tap water in the Northern Territory town of Katherine — which includes a "designer" mix of river water from the world-famous Nitmiluk National Park and mineral-rich groundwater — has been named Australia's best drop.

title.children: PFAS to perfection: The story behind regional NT town's 'designer' water

image.altText: Emergency department of hospital with sunset behind it

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory coroner has determined a series of human errors contributed to the 2022 death of an Indigenous woman at Royal Darwin Hospital, in the weeks after she sought a routine surgery.

title.children: 'Chain of errors' contributed to woman's death after routine surgery: coroner

image.altText: A baby wombat lies in a blanket in a person's arms.

props.synopsis: There are about 40-50 active volunteer carers within ACT Wildlife, but the organisation says more are needed, especially as the temperature soars.

title.children: 'Terrible job to cuddle baby wombats': Behind the scenes as a wildlife carer

image.altText: A Menorah moved to Bondi Beach by Waverley Council.

props.synopsis: After growing calls for a royal commission into the Bondi terror attack, the prime minister has finally announced it would take place, saying it "was what Australia needs".

title.children: The Bondi royal commission is due to report in April. Here's what we know

image.altText: Wrexham players celebrate during FA Cup win over Nottingham Forest.

props.synopsis: As actor and co-owner Ryan Reynolds watched on in the grandstand, Wrexham defeated Nottingham Forest on penalties to advance to the fourth round of the FA Cup.

title.children: Hollywood-backed Wrexham knocks Premier League side out of FA Cup

image.altText: People singing and dancing at the Parkes Elvis Festival.

props.synopsis: Japanese tribute artist Toki Toyokazu is part of a growing international presence at the annual Parkes Elvis Festival, which also includes women.

title.children: English is Toki's second language, but he sings in a classic Elvis drawl

image.altText: Alex de Minaur touches his shirt on his left shoulder at the United Cup.

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur produces a signature tenacious display, but it is not enough to send Australia through to the United Cup semifinals in Sydney.

title.children: Aussies exit United Cup and Poland advances to semis

image.altText: Protesters gather in front of the US consulate during a demonstration in Nuuk

props.synopsis: The United States has a long history of wanting to acquire Greenland, but people living on the island say Donald Trump's latest comments about annexation feel different.

title.children: In Greenland, Trump's talk of annexation is stirring up a dark past

image.altText: A spotty-skinned bluey-grey shark with a milky eyeball that's got a white copepod hanging off it.

props.synopsis: The Greenland shark is thought to live for about 400 years but somehow its eyes appear to barely deteriorate, according to a new study that has implications for human health.

title.children: Greenland shark eyes may hold anti-aging secrets

image.altText: People in high-vis work with a ladder near an emergency truck and a metal-walled building.

props.synopsis: Experts say volunteering is not in decline, but it is becoming more spontaneous. The NSW disaster agency is moving to embrace this after seven women mobilised 1,200 people to volunteer for a day in record-breaking floods.

title.children: NSW SES to allow people to volunteer for a day when disaster strikes

image.altText: A woman holding on to the side of a helicopter with mountains in the background

props.synopsis: Behind every emergency in WA, from bushfires to whale rescues, a state duty officer is making critical decisions. New hire Erin Tassell is breaking new ground in a key government department.

title.children: Ex-helicopter firefighter breaks down gender barriers in WA

image.altText: Baggage stacked against a wall.

props.synopsis: A sixth man is charged over an alleged plot to import half a tonne of cocaine into Western Australia using an international livestock carrier.

title.children: Sixth man charged over alleged livestock carrier cocaine bust

image.altText: A close-up photo of a woman's face

props.synopsis: Palestinian author Randa Abdel-Fattah has called for her appearance at Adelaide Writers' Week to be reinstated after it was axed, but SA's Premier has continued to back the decision, as dozens of authors cancel their appearances.

title.children: Palestinian author calls for apology as dozens quit Adelaide Writers' Week
